name: Andrey Fradkin
title: Associate Professor
bio: Andrey Fradkin studies online marketplaces and platform economics. His research on Airbnb helped shape understanding of how digital platforms affect local markets. Previously worked at Indeed.com and continues to collaborate with major tech platforms on marketplace design.

papers.title: Search, Matching, and the Role of Digital Marketplace Design
papers.note: How Airbnb's design affects market outcomes

papers.title: The Welfare Effects of Peer Entry in the Accommodation Market

name: Chris Nosko
title: VP and Head of Science & Analytics
bio: Chris Nosko leads Uber's data science and analytics organization. Before Uber, he was a professor at Chicago Booth where he pioneered research on online marketplaces. His work on eBay auctions set the standard for empirical marketplace analysis.

papers.title: The Limits of Reputation in Platform Markets

name: Colin Gray
title: Economics & Data Science
bio: Colin Gray leads economics and data science at Netflix, where he applies causal inference and machine learning at scale. His research focuses on labor economics and the future of work, with influential papers on online labor markets.

papers.title: Do Ride-Sharing Services Reduce Traffic Congestion?
papers.note: Causal effects of Uber/Lyft on cities

name: Erik Brynjolfsson
title: Director, Stanford Digital Economy Lab
bio: Erik Brynjolfsson is the world's leading researcher on the economics of AI and digital transformation. His books 'The Second Machine Age' and 'Machine, Platform, Crowd' have shaped how we understand technology's impact on productivity and labor. He directs the Stanford Digital Economy Lab.

papers.title: The Turing Trap: The Promise & Peril of Human-Like AI
papers.note: Why AI should augment, not replace humans

papers.title: Generative AI at Work
papers.note: First rigorous study of ChatGPT productivity effects

papers.title: The Second Machine Age
papers.note: Influential book on AI and the economy

name: Hal Varian
title: Chief Economist Emeritus
bio: Hal Varian invented the role of 'Chief Economist' in tech when he joined Google in 2002. He designed Google's ad auction system, which generates over $200 billion annually. His textbook 'Intermediate Microeconomics' taught generations of economists. With Carl Shapiro, he wrote 'Information Rules,' the bible of internet business strategy.

papers.title: Information Rules
papers.note: The bible of internet business strategy

papers.title: Predicting the Present with Google Trends

name: John List
title: Chief Economist
bio: John List revolutionized how companies run experiments. As Chief Economist at Uber and Lyft, he built their experimentation platforms. His book 'The Voltage Effect' teaches how to scale successful experiments. He's the world's leading field experimentalist, ranked #5 most influential economist by RePEc.

papers.title: The Voltage Effect
papers.note: Why most ideas fail at scale

papers.title: The Behavioralist as Tax Collector
papers.note: Using nudges to increase tax compliance

name: Jonathan Hall
title: Chief Economist & Director of Public Policy
bio: Jonathan Hall is Uber's Chief Economist, responsible for pricing strategy including surge pricing. His research on the labor supply of Uber drivers reshaped how we understand gig work. Previously at Google and Pandora.

papers.title: An Analysis of the Labor Market for Uber's Driver-Partners
papers.note: Foundational research on gig work flexibility

papers.title: The Effects of Uber's Surge Pricing

name: Kyle Kretschman
title: Head of Economics
bio: Kyle Kretschman leads economics at Spotify, applying economic thinking to music streaming, creator payouts, and platform design. His team works on pricing, marketplace optimization, and understanding how users discover content.

name: Liran Einav
title: Professor
bio: Liran Einav pioneered the use of large-scale private sector data for economics research. His collaborations with Visa and e-commerce platforms produced landmark studies. He serves as a Senior Fellow at SIEPR and co-editor of leading journals.

papers.title: The Data Revolution and Economic Analysis
papers.note: How private data is transforming economics

papers.title: Consumer Spending and Economic Stimulus
papers.note: Using Visa data to track spending in real-time

name: Michael Luca
title: Professor
bio: Michael Luca is the leading researcher on platform design and the economics of reputation. His work with Yelp showed how online reviews reshape markets. With Susan Athey, he wrote the definitive paper on 'Economists (and Economics) in Tech Companies.'

papers.title: Economists (and Economics) in Tech Companies
papers.note: The definitive guide to being a tech economist

papers.title: Reviews, Reputation, and Revenue
papers.note: How Yelp stars affect restaurant revenue

name: Michael Ostrovsky
title: Professor & Co-Director, NBER Market Design
bio: Michael Ostrovsky is the theorist behind modern ad auctions. His work with Schwarz on generalized second-price auctions (used by Google and Yahoo) won the Kalai Prize. He's advised Google, Yahoo, LinkedIn, and Pinterest, and co-founded TopSort.

papers.title: Reserve Prices in Internet Advertising Auctions

name: Michael Schwarz
title: Corporate VP & Chief Economist
bio: Michael Schwarz leads Microsoft's Office of the Chief Economist. He was previously Chief Economist at Google Cloud and Head of Economics Research at Yahoo. With Ostrovsky, he designed the GSP auctions that power internet advertising.

papers.title: Internet Advertising and the Generalized Second-Price Auction
papers.note: The paper behind $100B+ in ad revenue

papers.title: Optimal Auction Design and Equilibrium Selection

name: Pat Bajari
title: Chief Economist & VP
bio: Pat Bajari built Amazon's economics team from scratch to 400+ PhD economists, creating the template that every tech company now follows. His empirical methods for studying auctions and contracts are foundational. He passed away in December 2025 at age 55.

papers.title: Identification and Estimation of a Structural Model
Machine Learning Methods Economists Should Know About

name: Patrick Hummel
title: Partner Director of Economics
bio: Patrick Hummel leads economics for Microsoft Cloud, working on pricing, capacity planning, and market design. Previously at Yahoo and Google, he worked on ad auction design with Preston McAfee.

papers.title: When Does Machine Learning Succeed in Predicting Winners?

name: Peter Coles
title: Head Economist for Policy
bio: Peter Coles leads economics at Airbnb, applying market design to the sharing economy. Previously Head Economist at eBay and professor at Harvard Business School. He trained under Nobel laureate Alvin Roth and designed the AEA job market signaling mechanism.

papers.title: Preference Signaling in Matching Markets
papers.note: Design of AEA job market signaling

name: Preston McAfee
title: Distinguished Scientist
bio: Preston McAfee is an auction design legend. He designed the FCC spectrum auctions with Milgrom and Wilson. As Chief Economist at Microsoft and VP at Yahoo, he built world-class economics teams. He founded ACM Transactions on Economics and Computation.

name: Scott Kominers
title: Professor & Research Partner
bio: Scott Kominers bridges market design theory and crypto/Web3 practice. He's a professor at Harvard Business School and Research Partner at a16z crypto. His work on NFTs and tokenomics shapes how we design digital marketplaces.

papers.title: Property Rights and the Efficiency of Bargaining
papers.note: Theory of property rights in markets

papers.title: How to Build a Low-cost ERC721

name: Sonia Jaffe
title: Principal Researcher
bio: Sonia Jaffe works in Microsoft's Office of the Chief Economist on antitrust, labor, and health economics. Her research on health insurance has influenced policy debates. Previously on the Stanford GSB faculty.

papers.title: The Welfare Implications of Health Insurance
Antitrust in the Age of Big Data

name: Steve Tadelis
title: Professor
bio: Steve Tadelis is the godfather of tech-economics field experiments. He led eBay's research team and served as VP at Amazon. His paper showing eBay was wasting millions on ads changed how tech companies think about marketing effectiveness.

papers.title: Consumer Acquisition Cost and Marketing Experiments at eBay
papers.note: The paper that proved eBay was wasting $millions on ads

papers.title: Reputation and Feedback in Online Markets

name: Susan Athey
title: Economics of Technology Professor
bio: Susan Athey is the most influential tech economist alive. The first female John Bates Clark Medal winner. She pioneered causal forests (machine learning for causal inference) and served as consulting Chief Economist at Microsoft. Past AEA President and member of the National Academy of Sciences.

papers.title: Generalized Random Forests
papers.note: The paper that launched causal ML

papers.title: The Impact of Machine Learning on Economics
Economists (and Economics) in Tech Companies
papers.note: Definitive guide for aspiring tech economists
